abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is uncertain. The key
            lessons indicate that consideration should have been given
            to private sector management, or ownership, as an
            alternative to relying on the public sector, including the
            viable option of introducing a management contract, or
            concession, which could have been evaluated as an
            alternative, prior to project approval. Although a law to
            reform the sector is under preparation, it is currently at a
            halt. Project design should allow for flexibility to take
            advantage of unforeseen developments during implementation,
            experienced by the expanded approach taken by the borrower,
            to include provision of bulk water to water kiosks in low
            income areas, and managed by the community, which proved
            successful, leading to considerable savings in potable water
            expenditures. But, careful assessment on the feasibility of
            institutional strengthening programs, should have been
            established at the early stages, with realistic objectives,
            particularly under unstable political environments. The
            absence of a close cooperation among co-financiers, hindered
            success, given the contradictory views on water facilities
            network expansion, and on institutional matters,
            particularly on the role, and timing of private sector
            involvement, harming the full commitment of stakeholders.

728852.subtopic:
Water Supply and Systems,Town Water Supply and Sanitation,Water Supply and Sanitation Governance
